instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00012: What is 820-00012? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3539: What is 820-3539? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: capacitor on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00012</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I have a MacBook Pro 13" 2015 with a minimal liquid damage on the i/o board (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00012</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>). One capacitor was very corroded, after removing it the short circuit was gone. I would like to replace that capacitor, but I don't know its parameters. Are schematics for i/o boards available anywhere?

threads.title: capacitor on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00012</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I only saw boardview available for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3539</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RIO board, which corresponds to <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> from 2014.
It will serve you, I hope.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1VEpF8usKzaNV-wK_GG6kaxG0cH8J-73f/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: capacitor on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00012</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Thank you! Unfortunately it looks pretty different from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00012</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Though, there is a group of components that looks identical, even though it is placed on the other side of the board . The capacitor that is missing on my board would correspond to <CAPACITOR>C9800</CAPACITOR>. But I guess there is no guarantee that it has the same parameters as the cap on the 2015 board, right?
As these i/o boards are very cheap, I guess it makes more sense to buy one and keep this one as a donor.

threads.title: capacitor on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00012</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You can follow the trace until RIO connector and find what power rail corresponds.
Then you know the nominal voltage required and make a guess about its capacitance, if is a filter cap.
If it is directly connected to some particular chip on the RIO board, you can use its datasheet, or check similar schematic.

In the above boardview, <CAPACITOR>C9800</CAPACITOR> is doubled by <CAPACITOR>C4690</CAPACITOR>.
If is similar in your board, remove and measure capacitance of second cap.
Or just use 10-22uF/6.3-10-16V capacitor...
